While they do have their limitations ( e. g. developmental compensation and strain effects in mouse lines not backcrossed adequately to a parental strain for a minimum of 10 generations), use of our inbred ( N20 generation) animals in the present study ( where no differences in locomotor behavior were detected between D2R - / - and D2R + / + mice; Figs. 1 & 2) revealed a previously unappreciated role of D2R - mediated signaling in associative learning and attention that could not be measured with the currently available, acutely administered D2R antagonists.

These findings are significant because D2R - / - mice respond to food reinforcers and ultimately form and maintain odor - driven S + / S - relationships ( a putative D1R - mediated behavior [ 6]) just as D2R + / + mice ( both groups achieved >= 80% discrimination accuracy, the dopamine D1Rs in our mice were not targeted).

Dopamine D2R - / - and D2R + / + mice ( n = 8 per group) were initially trained to ambulate the length of a polyvinyl mouse cage ( 30 - cm) to retrieve ~ 30 - mg of Pico (R) fat supplemented rodent food located in a small plastic cup ( 3 - cm) attached to the floor of the testing apparatus with Velcro.

When the mice encountered the inverted reinforcement contingencies during the first reversal learning session, the D2R - / - mice demonstrated an almost complete inability to inhibit responding to previously reinforced stimuli compared to D2R + / + mice ( * p < 0. 001).
Functional homologs of the evolutionarily conserved transforming acidic coiled coil ( TACC) gene family are present in organisms from yeast to man.

This mapping data, together with identification of a single TACC gene in the protostomes Caenorhabitis elegans, and Drosophila melanogaster [ 4 - 6], led to the speculation that the ancestral FGFR and TACC genes were located physically close to each other.

In accordance with the proposed quadruplication of the vertebrate genome during evolution, there is a fourth FGFR family member in vertebrates, raising the question of whether a fourth TACC gene is associated with FGFR4 in vertebrate genomes.
To date, only three active TACC genes have been cloned in humans [ 1 - 3], one in each of mouse [ 7], Xenopus laevis [ 8], D. melanogaster [ 4], and C. elegans [ 5, 6].

Examination of higher vertebrates led to the identification of splice variants of TACC1 and TACC2 in Mus musculus, and the assembly of the previously unidentified orthologues of TACC1 - 3 from Rattus norvegus.

Although the analysis of T. rubripes, rodents and humans so far suggests that the vertebrate TACC3 precursor was not included in the second round of genomic duplication, it could not be excluded that a TACC4 gene may have been lost during the evolution of these lineages.
The degree of similarity to the published sequence of human and mouse TACC3 suggested to us that TACC4 actually represents a partial rabbit TACC3 cDNA.
To test this hypothesis, we set out to clone the complete rabbit TACC3 sequence, based upon the known features of human and mouse TACC3.

This has provided further support that an ancient chromosomal segment was duplicated twice during vertebrate evolution, with the first duplication that gave rise to the human chromosome 4p16 / 5q32 - ter and human chromosome 8p / 10q23 - ter ancestors occurring in the early stages after the invertebrate divergence.

To investigate the role of this protein during mouse development, we generated a conditionally deleted allele of the Atrx gene in mouse embryonic stem ( ES) cells, and used these cells to examine the effect of ablating expression of the full - length Atrx protein in ES cells and in mouse embryos.
The failure to observe a truly null ATRX allele among human patients strongly suggests that, as in the mouse, the complete absence of ATRX protein is incompatible with human fetal survival.

Of interest are the phenotypic similarities and differences between our KA mutant mice and the previously described K14 - Delta N87 beta cat transgenic mice expressing stable beta - catenin under the control of K14 promoter [ 25] and K14 - Lef1 transgenic mice [ 27].
Surprisingly, our mutant mice shared more similarities with the K14 - Lef1 mice than the K14 - Delta N87 beta cat transgenic mice.

In addition, KA mutant mice displayed a disorganized hair coat beginning with the emergence of neonatal hairs, similar to that observed in K14 - Lef1 mice, whereas in K14 - Delta N87 beta cat mice, embryonic hair follicle morphogenesis was unaffected and other skin changes only emerged postnatally.
By crossing the heterozygous mice to FLPe deleter mice [ 34], PGKneor cassette was deleted in the germline by FRT - mediated recombination to generate mice with the final ApcCKO allele.

ApcCKO heterozygote mice were crossed with Cre deleter mice, EIIA - cre transgenic mice that express Cre in early embryo [ 35], to knockout the Apc allele in the germline, consequently creating a knockout strain ( Figure 1A).
The mice analyzed in this study were generated by crossing ApcCKO heterozygote mice of the F1 generation ( C57BL / 6J x 129 / S background) with K14 - cre transgenic mice ( FVB background).

Given our interest in human neurological disease we sought to identify any cognate human disorders where linkage had been established to the syntenic region of the human genome, but where no causal mutation had been identified.

First, the disease may be a result of haploinsufficiency at ITPR1; this concept is consistent with the observation that heterozygous deletion leads to a later onset disorder in humans, whereas homozygous deletion in mice leads to an early onset disorder, able to be expressed within the much shorter life span of the mouse.

Currently, the small number of aged Itpr1wt / Delta 18 animals precludes us from examining these mice for subtle signs and symptoms similar to those seen in SCA15 patients; however, these mice are clearly of interest to us as a potential model of SCA15.
